title: 103_s893
content: Section 315(a) of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to require television broadcasting stations to provide free broadcast time to qualified candidates for the office of United States Senator, with no censorship allowed. Licensees must offer equal opportunities for candidate use of their stations, except in specific circumstances. The Communications Act of 1934 requires broadcasting stations to provide equal opportunities for legally qualified candidates to use their stations, with no censorship allowed. There are exceptions for news appearances by candidates on newscasts, news interviews, news documentaries, and on-the-spot coverage of events. The Communications Act of 1934 mandates broadcasting stations to offer equal opportunities for candidates to use their stations, with exceptions for news coverage of events. The Federal Communications Commission, in consultation with the Federal Election Commission, determines the amount of television broadcast time for major-party candidates. The Federal Communications Commission, in consultation with the Federal Election Commission, determines the amount of television broadcast time for major-party candidates based on previous election usage. Candidates must receive enough broadcast time for a complete presentation of views, with details published in the Federal Register before each Senate election. This broadcast time is available during the forty-five-day period preceding the general election. The Commission ensures fair and equitable television broadcast time for candidates running for the United States Senate office, based on contributions received. Licensees must provide broadcast time at hours reflecting viewing habits. Candidates from parties with less than 5% of the popular vote in the last presidential election are granted broadcast time proportional to their contributions under $250. Licensees are required to pool broadcast time. The FCC mandates fair television broadcast time for Senate candidates based on contributions. Major parties need to enter pooling agreements to offset financial impacts. Legally qualified candidates must agree to forgo purchasing additional broadcast time and file an agreement with the Commission. Penalties apply for candidates who violate these conditions. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 mandates penalties for candidates who violate agreements on purchasing television broadcast time. Penalties include imprisonment or fines for candidates and disciplinary actions for licensees who exceed allocated time limits. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 imposes penalties for candidates who violate television broadcast time agreements, including fines or imprisonment. Amendments to related laws include changes to charges and exclusions from contributions definitions. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include provisions regarding the provision of television broadcast time without charge by licensees. The Federal Communications Commission is tasked with studying the application of these amendments to the first general election campaign conducted under the new provisions. The Federal Communications Commission will study the application of amendments to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, including recommendations for legislation. Rules to implement the Act must be promulgated within 180 days of enactment, with sections 1 and 2 taking effect on July 1st following the promulgation.
